snippet: Although companies can counter proxy servers, which mask a computer’s location, The Times was recently able to make bets on DraftKings from the six states where daily fantasy sports is considered illegal.
abstract: New York Times finds that fantasy sports players living in New York State can continue to place bets on DraftKings if using proxy server; process leaves DraftKings open to accusations that it is inviting users to evade laws in states that prohibit Internet gambling; fantasy sports, under 2006 federal law, is essentially unregulated, and it is unclear whether companies have any obligation to block such bets placed via proxy.

byline.original: By JAMES GLANZ and JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

lead_paragraph: Although companies can counter proxy servers, which mask a computer’s location, The Times was recently able to make bets on DraftKings from the six states where daily fantasy sports is considered illegal.

headline.print_headline: Ban or No Ban, Fantasy Site’s Back Door Is Open
headline.main: DraftKings Leaves Door Unlocked for Barred Fantasy Sports Players
